Which of the following statement is true of aj[`sym`time;trade;quote] in order to optimise performance?

options.text: The trade table should have time in ascending order
The quote table should have the parted or grouped attribute on sym, and the sorted attribute on time

options.d: The trade table should have the parted or grouped attribute on sym

options.text: The quote table should have the parted or grouped attribute on sym. aj expects that time will be in ascending order within each sym.

options.text: upsert works only when the left argument is a keyed table

questions.question: If I run h(+;4;`hey) from process A on a remote process B, and the error trap is not set on A or B:

options.text: There will be no error because the error trap has not been set on either process
There will be a type error on B but nothing on A

options.d: There will be a type error on A but nothing on B

options.text: There will be an error on both because type always throws an error

questions.question: If I run h(+;4;`hey) from process A on a remote process B, and the error trap is set on A and B:

options.text: There will no error on either because type does not throw an error over a handle
There will be a type error on B and A will hang

options.d: There will be a type error on A and B will hang

options.text: There will be an error on both because type always throws an error

questions.question: What is the difference between moving into a namespace .test with \d to define a function foo, and just defining it with .test.foo:?

options.text: They are similar but with \d you need to use :: when defining foo
In the \d case, foo will look in .test for global variables, in the other case it looks in the root namespace
In the \d case, foo will look in the root namespace for global variables, in the other case it looks in the .test namespace
